p: Thanks for the information. No hubbud at all - letters just make it seem so. Had we merely talked about it, there would not have been so much seeming circumstanbiality. I had hoped to be able to bring a whole system of conventional fastening for the legs; but I'm afraid this wouldn't fit your plan' so I'll bring the legs nicely tapered & smoothed. The fastening can be done with glued blocks, I think. Yes, walnut is darling stuff. I love the feel of it too; but I'm all for work in very hard materials now, I mean crystals, of course.

We've done very well so far with the books. I've received $200, and another check for $100 is due now. I have not yet even offered the very considerable collection of rare Western items, from which I expected most of the swag. Am just now ready to offer them to Chicago firm I know. the N.Y. outfit doesn't deal in Western Americana. So we should do very well before I'm through selling. And after the Western stuff, there's quite a bunch of other things.

There's something silly about the rare book game. For instance, one of my Frost items was valuable becuase of a printer's error. Another book is valuable because, in teh dedication to Edith Carow Roosevelt, the middle name is spelled "Karow." Piffle!
"I got sumpin you ain't got!" That's what makes rare volumes sell.
Fine findings & beautiful editions should bring a premium. I'm all for that.
